summary: This 1930 West African Court of Appeal decision involved an application for conditional leave to appeal to the Privy Council. The judgment awarded the plaintiffs-respondents a sum of £491 5s. 6d., which included interest. The appellant sought to include costs to exceed the £500 threshold required for appeal, but the court held that where an appeal is limited by the value of the matter in dispute, costs cannot be counted toward meeting the minimum amount. The court dismissed the application with costs, following precedents such as Doorga Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry and Great Western Ry. of Canada v. Braid.

judges.name: Young
judges.role: Acting Chief Justice of Sierra Leone

citations: Doorga Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry 8 Moo. 3rd app. 262
Great Western Ry. of Canada v. Braid, 1 Moo. P.C. (N.S.) 101
rationaleHighlights: Costs cannot be included to meet the appeal threshold when the underlying judgment is below the required value
Precedent establishes that only the substantive amount in dispute counts toward appeal eligibility
Application for leave to appeal dismissed where threshold not met
confidenceNotes: High confidence; information derived directly from judgment text and consistent with legal principles on appeal thresholds.
